metadata.title: Facile Preparation of Self-Assembled Layered Double Hydroxide-Based Composite Dye Films As New Chemical Gas Sensors

sections.text:
KEYWORDS: Langmuir film, LDH, Self-assembly, Gas sensor, Acid−base response
■ INTRODUCTION Hydrotalcite (LDH) is a class of anionic layered compounds that are similar in structure to clay.1 In general, the main layer of LDH consists of two kinds of metal hydroxides, so it is also called a layered double hydroxide, where the guest molecules or ions are highly ordered between the main layers.2 The basic structural formula is M2+1−xM 3+ x(OH)2(A
n−)x/n·mH2O, where M2+ represents a divalent metal cation, M3+ represents a trivalent metal cation, M3+/(M3+ + M2+) has a molar ratio represented by x, An− refers to an anion having n negative charges, and the amount of intercrystalline water is expressed by m.3 Over the past decade, the synthesis of LDH has made significant progress in new compositions and morphologies, which has allowed for continued improvements in many areas. The obvious performance of LDH is its effective properties in terms of anion exchange,4 composition flexibility,5 and biocompatibility.6 Therefore, it has attracted great attention in various supramolecular self-assembled materials fields such as catalysis,7 hydrogels,8 and supercapacitors.9 It has been reported that LDH and reduced graphene oxide were selfassembled to form a superlattice structure, and the superimposed two-dimensional atomic layer of LDH was fully utilized to form a supercapacitor with high cycle strength.10 Win et al. developed self-assembled covalently cross-linked
LDH nanocomposite hydrogels with ultrahigh water content and excellent mechanical properties.11 These studies have provided important clues for LDH as a self-assembling unit. Due to the high anion exchange capacity, the reported studies have indicated that the interlayer spaces of LDHs are embedded by various anions12,13 including tetraphenylporphyrin,14 polymers,15,16 anionic drug molecules,17 and other functional molecules,18−20 producing layered nanocomposites with expected functions.21 These hybrid materials were usually prepared in the form of powder, and the LDH powder had disadvantages such as the easy loss of the interlayer between sheets and difficulty in recovery. These disadvantages are not beneficial to real applications, so they are preferably fabricated into a controllable film structure at the molecular level. When the LDH layer is peeled off, a kinetically independent nanosheet layer can be formed. The positively charged nanosheet layer provides a primitive assembly for constructing the film material, and the primitive assembly can be used to construct a multilayer film material.
Received: March 29, 2019 Revised: May 6, 2019 Published: May 27, 2019

Dye molecules or ions can be adsorbed on some substrates to form aggregates22 through intermolecular van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonds, π−π stacking, and the synergistic effects of electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions.23−26 The cumulative arrangement of aggregates was presented as Hand/or J-form states. The H-type aggregate was specifically expressed as a parallel, face-to-face arrangement between dye molecules. The specific arrangement of the J-type aggregate is an axial head-to-tail arrangement. Two different ways of arrangement can be measured by spectroscopy, and the corresponding spectra are blue-shifted and red-shifted, respectively. Because the interaction between dye molecules is relatively fragile, once the surrounding environment changes, their internal cumulative arrangement can be easily changed. Some reports have shown that solvents, temperatures, and pH all affect the aggregation arrangement of the dye.27−30 Specifically, it can be characterized by ultraviolet spectroscopy to obtain the respective accumulation states of the dye molecules under different factors. Therefore, it is purposeful and useful to monitor the cumulative arrangement of dye molecules to form an organized structure. Interestingly, LDH is a new type of layered and highly ordered nanomaterial that can be used as a self-assembled unit to produce stable and orderly LDH/dye composite film structures. So far, self-assembled films have been developed using various synthesizing methods including drop-coating, infiltration self-assembly, layer-by-layer self-assembly, Langmuir− Blodgett (LB) self-assembly, etc.31,32 In comparison with various technologies, through LB assembly the films can be regulated with a controlled self-assembled arrangement and layer thickness as well as uniform surface.33,34 However, studies on the self-assembly of LDH and dye molecules via LB thin films have not been reported. In this work, the LB method was used to form an ultrathin film by the orderly assembly of LDH units. To obtain an LDH/dye LB film, it is necessary to overcome two major obstacles: the detachment of LDH in aqueous solution and the affinity of LDH with dye monomers and polymers. Although it has been found that dispersing LDH in an organic solvent (formamide) is relatively easy, one problem that still exists is that the aqueous dispersions need a long time to reach a distinct stratification state. Therefore, in the subsequent research, we needed to find a simple way to stratify LDH. The study of LDH intercalated with different groups in the field of membranes has attracted the interest of many scholars. Interestingly, Hu and Chen35 recently reported that hydroxyethyl sulfonate-inserted LDH (LDH-Ise) had excellent water-swelling properties. In addition, surface modifiers have been found to help increase the affinity of LDH with monomers and polymers. In this study, the LDHs, after the anion exchange of isethionate and the molecular phase of organic dyes, were assembled in an air−liquid interface, and the structure and properties of the membrane were studied. The microscopic morphology and self-assembly mechanism of the prepared LB film were studied by various characterization methods. It is worth noting that the color-reversible change and gas response of the prepared LDH-Ise composite film containing dye molecules under the action of acid gas and alkaline gas were investigated by spectroscopy.36 The research results in this work provide new ideas for wide practical applications of functional self-assembled films and acid-chromic materials, especially gas sensors, chemical switches, and gas-controlled color-change devices.
■ MATERIALS AND METHODS Materials. The dispersed Mg/Al-LDH-Ise nanosheets were synthesized according to the method previously reported.35 Methylene blue (MB) and neutral red (NR) were selected from the Aladdin Reagent Plant. Rhodamine B (RhB), Safranine T (ST), methanol (CH3OH), ethanol (C2H5OH), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 wt %), aqueous ammonia (NH3·H2O, 25 wt %), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were obtained from the Tianjin Kaitong Industry Chemical Reagent Company. All experimental water was filtered through a two-stage Milli-pore Milli-Q Plus purifier before use.
Preparation of LDH-Ise/Dye Langmuir Films. The surface pressure−molecular area (π−A) isotherm of the monolayer was measured using a commercially available KSV-NIMA LB tank (KN 2002, Biolin Scientific, Sweden), and an LB film was deposited at room temperature. We carefully cleaned the LB tank with ethanol and deionized water before the experiment. A solution of LDH-Ise in methanol was applied to the surface of a suspension of four different dyes (methylene blue (MB), neutral red (NR), Saffron T (ST), and Rhodamine B (RhB)) at a given concentration (1 × 10−3 mol/dm3). Here, the LDH-Ise powder was dispersed in mixed solvents of methanol and water (volume ratio 5:1) and used as a steady spreading dispersion solution. Then, 200 μL of an aqueous dispersion of LDHIse (0.8 mg/mL) was applied dropwise to the subphase surface with a microsyringe. The surface pressure was fed back to the control system after being measured by a tensiometer suspended from a Wilhelmy board. To sufficiently volatilize the solvent (methanol) to form a stable monolayer, we waited for ∼20 min for the coated film, the isothermal compression was then carried out at a velocity of 8 mm/ min, and we finally obtained the π−A isotherm.
For the convenience of the scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), SERS, UV−vis, and FT-IR spectroscopy measurements, the prepared LDH-Ise/dye monolayer and multilayer film were deposited on 20 mN of different solid matrixes (new exfoliated mica, quartz, glass, and CaF2). It should be noted that the quartz piece and the glass piece were pretreated with a ratio of NH4OH/H2O2/H2O solution in a volume ratio of 1:1:5, then rinsed again with deionized water. The LB composite film was transferred to the substrate by vertical lift at a speed of 2 mm/min, followed by the next morphological and spectral characterization.
Characterization. The morphology of the LDH-Ise/dye hybrid monolayer formed on different dye subphase suspensions was observed by electron microscopy (TEM, HT7700, High-Technologies Corp., Ibaraki, Japan). Samples were prepared by clamping the copper grid with pointed tweezers at a horizontal angle at the air/ suspension interface, and the floating LDH-Ise/dye mixed monolayer was transferred to the surface of a copper grid (400 mesh). The molecular orientation and microstructure of the LDH and LB composite membranes were characterized using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, SMART LAB, Rigaku). The contact angle of water at room temperature was measured using an OCA20 machine (Data Physics, Germany), and the obtained pictures were photographed with a Nikon (Tokyo) D90 A SLR camera. The samples were photographed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) model number FEI QUANTA FEG 250 (FEI Corporate, Hillsboro, OR, U.S.A.). The microstructure of the product was also depicted by a transmission electron microscope (TEM, HT7700, High-Technologies Corp., Ibaraki, Japan). Moreover, the analytical method of energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) was fully used to determine the nature of some chemical analysis. Depending on the conductivity of the product, the surface needs to be sprayed with gold particles to assist with conduction before the SEM measurement. The SERS test was performed by a confocal micro-Raman spectrometer (inVia) system using a laser model with a spot diameter of ∼1 μm, an incident power of 0.05 mW, and an excitation source at 532 nm. The fluorescence spectrum was measured using a HITACHI F-4500 spectrometer. The spectra were recorded after two accumulations with 10 s exposure time and 50× objective lens. The solid powder product could be tableted or the film could be directly transferred to a CaF2 substrate, and the FT-IR spectrum was surveyed using a
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10889
spectrometer by the Thermo Nicolet Corporation. To obtain the UV−vis spectrum of the product, the film was transferred to a quartz substrate and tested using a Shimadzu UV-2550 system.
■ RESULTS AND DISCUSSION First, the surface pressure−area (π−A) isotherm can clearly assist in observing information about the LB monolayer stability, molecular orientation, and phase transition at the gas/ liquid interface.37 From Figure 1a, when the volume of the used LDH-Ise dispersion was 200 μL, a Langmuir film formed on the surface of the RhB subphase by diffusion using a mixed solvent of different ratios. The obtained data show that the shape of the curve changes correspondingly with the change of the LDH-Ise dispersion in different volume ratios of methanol and water, and a certain collapse pressure was reached. The optimal extended solvent condition was methanol/water (v/v) at 5:1, and all subsequent experiments were measured in this condition. As shown in Figure 1b, the surface pressure−area (π−A) isotherm was obtained by spreading the dispersion on the surface of pure water and the aqueous dye subphase containing 10−3 mol/L MB, NR, RhB, or ST. It could thus be seen that the maximum surface pressure of LDH-Ise spread on the surface of pure water was ∼5 mN/m, which indicated that the prepared LDH-Ise had partially dissolved in water and could not form a stable film on the pure water surface. In contrast, significant changes could be observed in the isotherms of the surface diffusion of different dye molecules. When the MB and NR molecules were used as subphases, the curves could reach higher collapse pressures of 40 and 44 mN/m, respectively. The NR curve began to increase at a position where the area of the subphase trough was relatively large (i.e., 200 cm2), and the growth process of the surface pressure gradually increased, which also indicates that its average molecular occupation area was large. When RhB and ST molecules were used as subphase solutions, the formed films eventually collapsed at pressures of 30 and 35 mN/m, respectively. Although the curve was shown to rise at a trough area of ∼230 cm2, the corresponding surface pressure growth process was slow. As the area changed, a significant increase in surface pressure indicated that the formation of the LDH-Ise/dye composite membrane was due to some appropriate weak intermolecular interactions such as π−π stacking, hydrogen bonding, and the electrostatic forces among used dyes and LDH-Ise sheets. It is because of these weak
forces that the electrostatic repulsion between the LDH-Ise sheets is weakened, which is conducive to the formation of a uniform and dense composite monolayer.38
As shown in Figure 2, to evaluate the nanostructure of the prepared LDH-Ise/dye monolayer, photographs were taken by using TEM and scanning SEM. The LDH-Ise crystallites could clearly be seen in all of these images. In the TEM image depicted in Figure 2, it shows that the size of the LDH-Ise flakes (Figure 2a) after the ion exchange reaction ranged from 50 to 200 nm. Most sizes were around 100 nm. Due to its relatively reasonable effect with the isethionate, the sheet could be well-dispersed in water after peeling off, and the shape was similar to the appearance of a hexagonal plate, demonstrating the formation of LDH-Ise monolayers. Furthermore, membranes with different agglomerates could be observed. The LDH-Ise/MB film had high coverage on the surface of the substrate, so a uniformly distributed irregularly shaped sheet could be clearly observed in Figure 2b. In addition, Figure 2b shows that a small accumulation occurred in part of the LDHIse/MB film, which indicates that MB molecules are adsorbed on the surface of LDH-Ise flakes and form a relatively dense monolayer film. For the LDH-Ise/NR composite film, its surface formed as a chain structure with a plurality of sheets connected to each other as shown in Figure 2c. Compared to the LDH-Ise/MB film in Figure 2b, it was observed that the accumulation on the surface of the LDH-Ise/RhB film (Figure 2d) was more compact, and the large sheet surface collected numerous small dye molecules. Figure 2f was somewhat similar to Figure 2d, but the buildup on the LDH-Ise/ST film was thicker, probably because the ST molecule was more susceptible to interaction with the LDH-Ise flakes, causing the LDH-Ise surface to be neutral and also reducing the repulsion between the sheets. Furthermore, the surface appearance of the Langmuir film obtained in the four different dye subphase solutions was different, which may be mainly due to the structural difference of the dye molecules. From the SEM-mapping photograph (Figure 2g), it can be perceived that the film involved more Mg element and Al element, which are the two main components of the prepared LDH-Ise. In addition, it can be seen that the content of the S element was also relatively large, indicating that the S element was grafted onto the surface of LDH, further confirming that LDH-Ise was successfully prepared in the early stage. For the N elements, a small portion may have come from the original
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10890
LDH residues, although mostly from the MB dyes. It also contained a small amount of Cl, which was mainly present in the dye on the surface of LDH-Ise, rather than from the surrounding pollutants. In summary, the composite membranes were successfully prepared by LDH-Ise/dye molecules. The summary of the π−A isotherm measurements and the
TEM and SEM mapping observations show that the LDH-Ise floating monolayer was properly combined with the dye at the air/dye interface. At the same time, regularity was obtained by analyzing the Raman spectrum of LDH-Ise/MB film as shown in Figure 3. As the number of layers of the transfer film increased, the spectral intensity first increased and then decreased. It was apparent that the highest peak intensity was observed when 60 layers were transferred. Therefore, the transferred 60 layers of film were used to perform SERS testing at many different sites. It was found that the peak intensities at different positions of the same film were almost the same,
demonstrating that the film preparation was highly reproducible and also showing that a stable and uniform composite film formed at an external pressure of 20 mN/m. The best optative conditions for constituting the LDH-Ise/dye mixed film on a solid substrate were obtained. To fully demonstrate the molecular state of the film surface,
the measurement of the surface contact angle (Figure 4) and XRD (Figure S1) were also performed. As can be seen from Figure 4, the average contact angle of the sheet prepared from the original LDH-Ise to water was 52.3°, and the corresponding contact angles of the composite dye molecule (MB, NR, RhB, and ST) films were 89.5°, 79.8°, 85.5°, and 81.9°, respectively. Compared with the contact angle of the original LDH-Ise single-layer sheet, the average contact angle of the composite film was obviously increased, which further indicates that the dye molecular structure on the surface of the cast film forms a certain aggregation state, and the self-
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10891
assembled film has a certain hydrophobicity. In addition, the fundamental crystal planes (003), (006), (009), (015), (018), (110), and (113) of the precursor LDH-NO3 could be obtained from the XRD (Figure S1). In contrast, LDH-Ise showed a weakening and displacement at the main peak (003) plane. According to the literature,35 XRD also proves that ion exchange is successful, and the displacement of the main peak represents a large interlayer spacing. This change fully indicated that the LDH precursor had been stripped and the LDH-Ise was successfully prepared. In Figure S1, compared with the main crystal (003) planes of LDH-Ise, the XRD diffraction curves of the obtained LB composite films were slightly shifted. This phenomenon indicates that the dye molecules could have agglomerated with some LDH-Ise sheets through some weak intermolecular forces. Next, to study the accumulation of dye molecules on the
floating layer of the film, a composite multilayer LDH-Ise/dye film diffused on different subphases was transferred to a quartz substrate using a horizontal lift method with a surface pressure of 20 mN/m. For comparison, the UV−visible absorption
spectra of the aqueous dye solution and the LDH-Ise spreading solvent are also shown in Figure 5. Some information can be explicitly seen in Figure 5a. The MB solution showed two main characteristic absorption peaks, i.e., at 664 nm, which was designated as monomer absorption, and at 613 nm, as the shoulder peak designated as the H-aggregate.25,30 In addition, the LDH-Ise/MB composite films showed a maximum absorption peak at 618 nm, which could be due to the Haggregation of MB molecules. Another weak shoulder at 676 nm could be assigned to J-aggregate in films. In contrast, the NR molecular solution had a strong monomer absorption peak located at 523 nm, as shown in Figure 5b. The composite film of LDH-Ise/NR showed a maximum absorption peak near 463 nm, which was blue-shifted relative to the dye solution and formed an H-type aggregate. It was observed in Figure 5c that the RhB solution showed a strong monomer absorption peak at 559 nm and a shoulder peak near 515 nm, indicating that RhB molecules appeared in monomer and H-aggregate state in aqueous solution. However, the bands of the LDH-Ise/RhB composite film red-shifted at 527 and 569 nm probably due to
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10892
the formation of H-type and J-type aggregates in the LDH-Ise films based on exciton theory.39,40 Similarly, the characteristic peak positions of the ST composite films shifted to 502 nm in the LDH-Ise/ST films compared with the ST dye solution at 519 nm, as shown in Figure 5d. This also suggests the formation of H-aggregates of dye molecules in the functionalized LDH sheets in the composite films. In addition, the fluorescence spectra of the LDH-Ise solution, dye solutions, and the LDH-Ise/dye composite films are displayed in Figure
S2. From the obtained spectra, it was found that the peak positions of the composite films produced a red-shifted or blue-shifted change compared to the original LDH-Ise and dye solutions. The results observed further verified the different aggregation states of dye molecules in composite films under the influence of various weak forces. FT-IR can reflect the vibration of the chemical bonds of
various substances in a multilayer composite membrane, so the existence state of the substances in the composite films can be clearly characterized. As shown in Figure S3, compared with the original intrinsic LDH-NO3, the characteristic peak of the nitrate group at 1382 cm−1, after the ion exchange of LDH-Ise, almost disappeared and the SO bond and the S-phenyl band vibration appeared at 1198 and 1042 cm−1, respectively.41 The characteristic peak near 618 cm−1 could be attributed to the psubstituted phenyl characteristic vibration of the sulfonic acid group (Figure S3). These data demonstrate the successful ion exchange of sulfonic acid groups between the LDH-NO3 molecular layers. Then, in the FT-IR spectrum of the LDHIse/dye film as shown in Figure 6, it can be seen that there were two peaks at 2918 and 2848 cm−1, which represent the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations peak of the C−H bond on the methyl group on the MB and NR structures, respectively. The N−H bond vibration absorption peak of NR appeared at 3391 and 3190 cm−1. The positively charged amino group in the NR molecule may electrostatically interact with the sulfonic acid group of LDH-Ise to shift the N−H bond absorption peak position.42 For the LDH-Ise/ST
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10893
image, the peaks at 3349 and 3212 cm−1 corresponded to the N−H stretching vibration peak of NR, except that displacement occurred in different cases, which suggests that there may be different strong hydrogen bonds in the LDH-Ise/ST composite membrane. RhB showed a typical CO peak at 1718 cm−1.43 Other bands at 1637, 1598, 1646, 1612, and
1589 cm−1 are attributable to the benzene ring surface skeleton of the MB, NR, RhB, and ST components CC and C−N plane vibration peaks.44−52 Compared to the LDH material originally used, the benzene ring skeleton of these composite membranes exhibits different positions of extension, indicating that hydrogen bonding and electrostatic interaction between
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10894
LDH-Ise and the dye molecules is stronger.53 The above results indicate that the dye molecules are present on the surface of LDH-Ise. Acid-induced discoloration refers to the reversible change in the color of a solution or film that occurs as the pH of the solution changes, or when the film is in contact with an acid− alkaline solution gas.54−57 These changes can be examined by UV−vis and FT-IR spectroscopy and are shown in Figures 7 and 8. In this study, the LDH-Ise/NR (Figure 7a) and LDHIse/RhB (Figure 7b) acid−base discoloration properties in LB films were characterized as typical models, and the other two films are also shown in Figure S4. Observation and comparison showed that the obtained LB film was very sensitive to the pH environment. When the pH value changed, the original absorption peak of the films underwent a red-shift or blueshift in the UV−vis spectra. From Figure 7a, the LDH-Ise/NR film had a broad peak around 463 nm and red-shifts to 544 nm after exposure to HCl gas. At the same time, significant color changes were observed under alternating exposure to HCl and NH3 atmospheres. Figure 7b shows that the initial state color of the LDH-Ise/RhB film was dark pink, and the color was nearly transparent after a certain concentration of HCl gas. The UV−vis spectrum showed that the peak position moved
from 559 to 569 nm, indicating reaction with a certain concentration of NH3 gas to produce a light pink color, and the absorption vertex basically returned to the primary position. The main influencing factor in this situation was the change in pH from the use of solvents and the presence of heteroatoms (such as nitrogen atoms) in the molecular structure of the membrane material, which caused the structure of the compound to change and affect the charge transfer. In addition, to compare the gas-sensing properties of the LDHIse/dye composite LB films, LDH-Ise/dye mixed cast films were also prepared and characterized, and the UV−vis data for LDH-Ise/dye cast films are shown in Figure S5. It can be clearly observed that the maximum absorption peak position of the LDH-Ise/dye cast films also shifted during the exposure of the same gas atmosphere for 1 min, but their shift change was not significant. At the same time, as seen by comparing the photos before and after the reaction, the cast films had almost no change in surface color, which could be assigned to the fact that LDH-Ise and dye molecules were randomly stacked in the cast films. Once exposed to an acidic or basic gas atmosphere, only a small portion of molecules on the surface was involved in the reaction. As a result, the color-change levels of the four LDH-Ise/dye cast films were greatly reduced, and the gas sensitivity was also weak. Compared to LDH-Ise/dye cast films, it was confirmed that the gas sensitivity of the LDH-Ise/ dye composite films obtained by the LB self-assembly technique was remarkably better. Moreover, the FT-IR spectrum in Figure 8 shows that the dye composite LB film was exposed to HCl and NH3 gases at different times, showing a continuous process of change. Compared with the original intrinsic film, it can be seen from the FT-IR spectrum that the absorption peak of the LDH-Ise/ dye was blue-shifted. After the HCl atmosphere, the LB film had a strong absorption peak in the range of 3500−3200 cm−1 and showed two strong sharp peaks in the range of 3000−3200 cm−1 in the FT-IR spectrum after NH3 action. This may be due to the tensile vibration behavior of the ammonium salt produced by the action of the composite films with two gases.57−63 As the exposure time to NH3 gas increased, a new strong sharp peak was produced at 1405 cm−1. It is possible that the stretching vibration or protonation of the amide group caused the generation of a peak. The LB composite films were quite sensitive to the induction of acid−base gases, and the reaction time was quite short in both the HCl atmosphere and the NH3 atmosphere. In fact, it can be seen that the color changed significantly within 5 s. Thus, 1 min was chosen for the test time to ensure that the composite films reacted completely with the gas molecules. All of these can measure the intensity change of the maximum absorption peak by ultraviolet spectroscopy and then further determine the response time and recovery time of the LDH-Ise/dye films. In this process, as the exposure time of the HCl or NH3 gas increases, the response times of the LB films are shorter, the sensitivity is higher, and the color change of the films is more obvious, which also corresponds to the photograph shown in Figure 7. If the reaction time exceeded 1 min, then the color of the films stabilized and would not change again. At the same time, these changes shown in Figure 9 were reasonably presumed to be the protonation and deprotonation of N−H and −NH2 groups attached to the benzene ring segment in the dye molecules in the prepared LB composite films. These amine groups contained lone electron pairs, which were prone to protonation
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10895
under HCl gas atmosphere, and were combined with one H atom as a coordination bond. Furthermore, the entire molecule was positively charged, changing the conjugated absorption and π−π* transition of the aromatic hydrocarbon site.53 Then, under the NH3 gas atmosphere, the pH of the environment
increased, and the corresponding amino group deprotonated.
Thereafter, as the acid and alkali gases circulated, the situations
of the assimilation peaks in the spectra fundamentally
maintained at a certain value. The occurrence of the above
DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780 ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7, 10888−10899
10896
phenomenon may be related to the ammonium chloride salt formed on the surface of the LB films. To investigate the possible selectivity of the prepared gas
sensor, several other acid gases were also investigated. For example, the LB composite films were exposed to a volatile gas atmosphere such as HF, CH3COOH, CO2, etc. The color change of the LB composite films was not obvious even after 15−20 min, which demonstrated the good selectivity of HCl gas via the gas sensor films. On the other hand, the prepared LDH-Ise/dye composite films by LB self-assembly demonstrated stable and selective functional material. The repeatability of this sensor system has always been an important issue of concern. To facilitate recycling, each time the HCl and NH3 gas atmosphere acts on the LDH-Ise/dye composite films, the ammonium chloride salt formed on the surface can be easily detached by soaking once in ultrapure water. Subsequently, the next acid−base system gas response can be performed again. Looped multiple times, the test results are shown in Figure 10. The ordinate on the graph shows the UV maximum absorbance intensity ratio In/I0 of the LB composite films where I0 represents the maximum UV absorbance for the composite films that were not affected by the gas and In represents the ultraviolet maximum absorbance of the composite films after a certain cycle. The analysis showed that the UV intensity ratios of the four different LDH-Ise/dye films were in the range of 94% after 10 cycles. These results demonstrate that the composite films showed good durability and recyclability with wide potential applications. Inspired by the previous research studies on composite films and acid−base response,40,64 the acid−base response performance of the present obtained composite LDH-Ise films were also characterized. The selected MB, NR, RhB, and ST dye molecular space filling models were depicted by the front or side view, and structural differences can be seen obviously in Figure 11. In addition, because the acid−base response process of only one dye molecule was used as a typical model in Figure 9, several other molecules are shown to form a more intuitive comparison in Figure 11. These four dyes are similar in that they contain larger heterocyclic conjugated systems, which can form H- and/or J-type aggregates in different LDH-Ise composite LB films. Combining the data obtained earlier, a schematic diagram of the self-assembly process of the LDHIse/dye composite Langmuir film was simply drawn. The initial prepared LDH-NO3 appearance was similar to that shown in Figure 12, and its basic molecular structure diagram was also clearly depicted. The sulfonate ion successfully acted on the surface of the hydrotalcite and exchanged the anions in the gap. The product obtained in this step exhibited good water dispersibility, and the nanosheet could be well-separated. In combination with the LB technique, the entire impregnated dye solutions were used as the subphase, and the dispersion was then diffused onto the surface using a microinjector. Both sides of the obstacle were uniformly pressed toward the center to form the desired LB composite film. Finally, different aggregation states of dyes appeared to form, which were easy to transfer to a multilayer composite film material. In addition, the composite films showed good sensitivity and recyclability under HCl and NH3 gas conditions. Therefore, it has broad application prospects and expands new ideas for the research of gas sensor film materials and other self-assembled nanocomposites in the future.65−70
■ CONCLUSIONS In summary, a novel ordered LDH-Ise/dye self-assembled composite multilayer film was successfully fabricated at the air−water interface by the anion exchange method and LB technique. In composite films, positively charged LDH-Ise sheets can induce the formation of aggregates of different dye molecules, referred to as J- and/or H-aggregates. The characteristics of the various aspects of LB composite films were listed in a number of measurements. In addition, when the obtained composite film was repeatedly circulated to the atmosphere of HCl and NH3, the molecular structure of the dye on the surface of the LB film changed with the phenomenon of acid−base discoloration, and the sensitivity of the film to pH was investigated by UV−vis and FT-IR spectroscopy. Therefore, the LDH-Ise/dye composite membrane can be used as a functional material for pH-sensitive performance testing, and the current work provides useful clues for LB membrane self-assembly and acid−base discoloration characteristics. It is expected to be used as a promising molecular switch and chemical sensor.
■ ASSOCIATED CONTENT *S Supporting Information The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01780.

metadata.abstractText: The useful functionalization and self-assembly of two-dimensional layered materials like hydrotalcite (LDH) are critical for the wide application of nanomaterials. In this work, some self-assembled Langmuir films of ion-exchanged LDH and dyes with different molecular structures were prepared by the Langmuir−Blodgett (LB) technique. The aggregation states of used dye molecules on the surface of the obtained membrane and the structures/properties of the membrane were studied. The hydroxyethyl sulfonate-inserted LDH (LDH-Ise) nanosheets were able to induce the dye formation of highly ordered Hand/or J-aggregate structures. Surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy results demonstrated the uniformity and repeatability of the film. Interestingly, the good acid−base gas response characteristics of present LDH-Ise/dye LB films were investigated by UV−vis and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR). The present research work provides new clues for the development of gas sensors and chemical switches as well as the preparation of effective functional self-assembled films.
